hints.content:
There are lots of ways we can think about the **typical** number of chocolate chips.

- What was the most common number of chocolate chips?
- If we split the chocolate chips evenly among all the cookies, how many chips would each cookie have?
- What would be the balance point of the data?
- What is the middlemost number of chocolate chips?
If we split the chocolate chips evenly, each cookie would have $4$ or $5$ chips.

If we put our dot plot on a balance scale, it would balance when the pivot was between $4$ and $5$ chocolate chips.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/9dc32a86d46ff26c4113070f6707c25b1a43458b)

The scale would tip if, for example, we put the pivot at $2$ chocolate chips.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/08818fcfbb9c4817eb5deaf797110aaae949b072)
About half of the cookies have $4$ or fewer chocolate chips and about half have $5$ or more chocolate chips.
Of the choices, it is reasonable to say there are typically about $5$ chocolate chips in one of Shawn's cookies.

question.content:
The following dot plot shows the number of chocolate chips in each cookie that Shawn has. Each dot represents  a different cookie.

[[☃ image 1]]

**Which of the following is a typical amount of chocolate chips in one of Shawn's cookies?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: Most of the cookies had more than $2$ chocolate chips.
All of the cookies had fewer than $10$ chocolate chips.
All of the cookies had fewer than $18$ chocolate chips.
